DataElement.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Histologic Grade Cellular Differentiation Assessment Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The category related to the histologic grade and degree of cellular differentiation in a malignant neoplasm specimen.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Malignant Neoplasm Histologic Grade Cellular Differentiation Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the histologic grade and degree of cellular differentiation in a malignant neoplasm specimen.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.:In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.:Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

DataElementConcept.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 02/03/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term used to describe cells or tissues that do not have specialized ("mature") structures or functions. Undifferentiated cancer cells often grow and spread quickly.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost all of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread quickly and aggressively.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally retain the appearance of normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Category; used informally to mean a class of things.
